add essentialism, constructivism and instrumentalism down here
/* Ethnicity and race */ doing justice to Wolf, put examples in note
/* Conceptual history of ethnicity */ partly ce, some slight adjustments (hopefully correct)
/* Defining ethnicity */ add wallman quote about ordinary langauge use
/* Ethnies and Ethnic categories */ expand with new ref
remove bad ref for this fact
/* Ethnicity and race */ remove gigantic block quote based on a kind of outdated (apparently marxist) understanding of ethnicity
/* Defining ethnicity */ expand, reorganize move around
/* Primordialist or Perennialist ethnicity */ continue expansion
/* Defining ethnicity */ more history of the term
/* Defining ethnicity */ moving bits around and creating a new section to hold some of the contrasting definitions of ethnicity
change ancestry to heritage - since heritage can be both cultural and biological
strike endogamy - none of the sources seem to imply this

Revert unexplained deletion of sourced material. Please take it to the talk page.
/* See also */ An article on UK census categories from a specific year is too specific for the 'see also' section of this page
Source does not say that. The source (that is given too much prominence in my view) does not speak of malleable definitions but about a malleable phenomenon. Like Barth and Wolf, actually.

Revert: an ethnic group doesn't need to share specific biological traits. An ethnic group is anthropologically, not biologically defined.

[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 215472243 by [[Special:Contributions/Slrubenstein|Slrubenstein]] Latin Europeans are not hispanic/latino in U.S. Spaniards are hispanic since they speak Spanish
In the US, people from Spain are not classified as Latinos or Hispanics
/* Ethnicity in specific countries */ Latin Europeans (French, Italian, Romanian, Spanish,...) maybe considered Latin, but they are not Hispanic or Latino in the US (except sometimes Spaniards)
